title: Let's learn OpenClaw
description: Install OpenClaw, set up a Docker sandbox, and message your personal AI agent from your phone. ~15 minutes.

cards.title: Let's learn OpenClaw
cards.body: By the end of this lesson, you'll have a personal AI agent running on your machine that you can message from your phone. It'll take about 15 minutes.

cards.title: First — how would you describe yourself?
cards.body: This helps us adjust the lesson for you.

choices.label: Creative / non-technical
choices.desc: Designer, writer, marketer. Terminal sounds scary.

choices.label: Tech-comfortable
choices.desc: I use dev tools but I'm not a programmer. I've used Claude Code, ChatGPT, etc.

choices.label: Developer
choices.desc: I write code. I know what Docker is.

cards.title: OpenClaw is an AI agent that lives on your computer
cards.body: You already use AI through chat windows — Claude, ChatGPT. OpenClaw is different. It runs on your machine, connects to your messaging apps, and can actually do things for you.

analogy.text:
Claude Code is like a coworker who sits next to you at your desk. You talk, they help, then they leave.

OpenClaw is like a personal assistant who has the keys to your apartment. They're always there, checking your mail, organizing your calendar, sending messages on your behalf — even when you're not home.

cards.title: What sounds most useful to you?
cards.body: Pick what gets you excited. There's no wrong answer.

choices.label: Message it from my phone
choices.desc: Send a WhatsApp message and have it do stuff on my computer

choices.label: Just curious, honestly
choices.desc: I want to see what the hype is about

cards.title: Let's talk about the elephant in the room
cards.body: OpenClaw gets access to your computer. Terminal, files, everything. That's what makes it powerful — but it's also what makes people nervous. And honestly? You should be a little nervous. That's healthy.
cards.warn: If someone sends your agent a cleverly-worded message, it could theoretically run commands on your machine. This is called prompt injection.
cards.cta: Okay, so how do we stay safe?

cards.title: Docker: your safety net
cards.body: Here's the good news: we can put OpenClaw inside a container — a sealed box on your computer. The agent can do its thing inside the box, but it can't touch anything outside. Your files, your passwords, your photos — all protected.

analogy.text: Think of Docker like a sandbox at a playground. The kid (your AI agent) can build whatever they want inside the sandbox. But they can't dig into your yard, your house, or your neighbor's property. Everything stays contained.

cards.title: Quick check
cards.question: Why do we use Docker with OpenClaw?

options.text: It keeps the AI agent contained so it can't access your personal files
Docker is required — OpenClaw won't work without it
It's just a trendy developer thing

cards.correctFeedback: Exactly. Docker creates a safe boundary. OpenClaw works fine without it — but with it, you get peace of mind.
cards.wrongFeedback: Not quite. Docker creates a safe boundary around OpenClaw so it can't access your personal files. OpenClaw works without Docker, but it's much safer with it.

cards.title: Do you have Docker installed?
cards.body: We need it for the safe setup.

cards.title: Let's make sure Docker is ready
cards.body: Open your terminal and type this:
cards.codeCaption: If you see a version number, you're good. If you see an error:
cards.body2: Download Docker Desktop from docker.com, install it, and make sure it's running (you'll see a whale icon in your menu bar).

troubleshoot.label: "command not found: docker"
troubleshoot.fix: Docker isn't installed yet. Download it from docker.com, run the installer, then open Docker Desktop from your Applications folder. Wait for the whale icon to appear in your menu bar before trying again.

troubleshoot.label: Docker version shows but commands fail
troubleshoot.error: Cannot connect to the Docker daemon
troubleshoot.fix: Docker is installed but not running. Open Docker Desktop from your Applications folder and wait for it to start (whale icon in menu bar stops animating). Then try again.

cards.title: Next: make sure Node.js is installed
cards.body: OpenClaw needs Node.js version 22.12 or higher. Check yours:
cards.codeCaption: You need to see v22.12.0 or higher. Not v20, not v18 — specifically v22.12+.
cards.body2: If your version is too old or you get an error, you'll need to upgrade.

troubleshoot.label: My version is v20 or v18 (too old)
troubleshoot.fix:
If you use nvm (check with nvm --version):
nvm install 22
nvm use 22
nvm alias default 22

If you don't use nvm, download the latest v22 LTS from nodejs.org and run the installer. It'll replace your current version.

After upgrading, close your terminal, open a new one, and run node --version again to confirm.

troubleshoot.label: "command not found: node"
troubleshoot.fix: Node.js isn't installed. Download it from nodejs.org (pick the LTS version, currently v22). Run the installer, then open a new terminal window and try node --version again.

troubleshoot.label: I upgraded but it still shows the old version
troubleshoot.fix:
Your terminal is caching the old path. Try these in order:
1. Close your terminal completely and open a new one
2. Run which node to see which Node it's using
3. If you use nvm: nvm use 22 then nvm alias default 22
4. If you installed from nodejs.org: the installer may need a restart to update your PATH

cards.title: Wait — didn't we just talk about Docker?
cards.body: Good instinct. Here's how it works:
bullets: OpenClaw itself installs on your machine — just like any app. This is safe. It's just software sitting there.
The AI agent is the part that actually runs commands and does things. That's the part we put inside Docker.
Think of it this way: you install the remote control (OpenClaw) normally. The robot (the agent) goes in the sandbox.
cards.safe: The next step installs OpenClaw. This is like downloading an app — it doesn't do anything until you tell it to. The sandboxing comes later, when we activate the agent.

cards.title: Now the fun part — install OpenClaw
cards.body: One command. That's it.
cards.body2: This installs OpenClaw globally so you can run it from anywhere in your terminal. It might take a minute.

helpItems.q: Is this safe? What does 'globally' mean?
helpItems.a: Global just means you can run the openclaw command from any folder. It's like installing an app to your Applications folder vs. only one specific folder. No code runs until you explicitly start it.
Nope — OpenClaw itself is just a tool, like installing Slack or VS Code. The agent (the part that runs commands) is what goes in the Docker sandbox. We'll set that up in a few steps.

troubleshoot.label: EACCES / permission denied
troubleshoot.error: npm ERR! Error: EACCES: permission denied
troubleshoot.fix:
Your system needs elevated permissions for global installs. Run:
sudo npm install -g openclaw@latest
It'll ask for your computer password. This is normal.

troubleshoot.label: npm: command not found
troubleshoot.fix: npm comes bundled with Node.js. If this happens, go back to the previous step and install Node.js first. Once Node is installed, npm will be available too.

troubleshoot.label: Network / timeout errors
troubleshoot.fix: Check your internet connection and try again. If you're behind a VPN or corporate firewall, try disconnecting the VPN temporarily.

cards.title: Heads up — you're about to see a scary warning
cards.body: When you run the wizard, OpenClaw will show a security warning in red text. It says things like "hobby project", "still in beta", "a bad prompt can trick it into doing unsafe things."
cards.body2: Your gut reaction will be: should I even be doing this? That's normal. Here's how to read it:
bullets: This is actually a good sign. The developers are being transparent about the risks instead of hiding them.
"Hobby project" doesn't mean unsafe. It means a small team, moving fast. Linux started as a hobby project.
The risks it describes are real — and that's exactly why we set up Docker. The sandbox makes those risks manageable.
It'll ask: "I understand this is powerful and inherently risky. Continue?" Say Yes.

cards.title: Run the setup wizard
cards.body: This walks you through configuring everything:
cards.body2: The wizard will ask you a bunch of questions. Don't stress — here's what to pick for each one. We'll go through them together on the next screens.

helpItems.a: A daemon is a program that runs in the background. This flag tells OpenClaw to set itself up so it can keep running even when you close the terminal.

helpItems.q: Can I redo the wizard later?
helpItems.a: Yes! You can run openclaw onboard again anytime to reconfigure. Nothing is permanent.

troubleshoot.label: "openclaw requires Node >=22.12.0"
troubleshoot.fix:
Your Node.js version is too old. You need v22.12 or higher.

If you use nvm:
nvm install 22
nvm use 22
nvm alias default 22

Then open a new terminal window and try again.

troubleshoot.label: "command not found: openclaw"
troubleshoot.fix:
OpenClaw didn't install properly. Go back and try:
npm install -g openclaw@latest

If that gives a permission error:
sudo npm install -g openclaw@latest

cards.title: Wizard: Gateway type → Local
cards.body: It asks: Local or Remote?

concept.label: What to pick
concept.title: Local
concept.desc: You're running this on your own computer. Pick Local.

cards.title: Wizard: Workspace → Default
cards.body: It asks where to store OpenClaw's files.

concept.label: What to pick
concept.title: Just press Enter (accept the default)
concept.desc: It'll use ~/.openclaw which is fine. No need to change this.

cards.title: Wizard: AI Model — this one matters
cards.body: The wizard asks which AI provider to use. This is where you choose the brain powering your agent.

concept.label: Two good options
concept.title: Pick based on whether you want to pay or not

bullets: Free option: Google → Gemini Flash. 20 free requests/day. No credit card needed. Perfect for trying things out.

Paid option: Anthropic → Claude Opus. Best quality and most secure against prompt injection. But you need a funded Anthropic API account — go to console.anthropic.com, add a payment method, and buy credits before you pick this option.
cards.warn: Important: An API key is not the same as a subscription. Even if you pay for Claude Pro ($20/month), that doesn't give you API credits. The API is billed separately at console.anthropic.com.

cards.title: Wizard: Everything else → Defaults
cards.body: For the remaining questions:
bullets: Gateway port → Default (18789)
Gateway bind → Loopback (most secure)
Tailscale → Off
Chat channels → If it offers WhatsApp, go ahead and set it up now! It'll show a QR code — scan it with your phone.
Skills → Skip (we'll add later)
Hooks → Enable boot.md
Service runtime → Node
cards.safe: If you see a default option, pick it. You can always change these later.

cards.title: Say hello to your agent
cards.body: The wizard is done. Now launch the terminal interface:
cards.body2: Your agent wakes up and introduces itself. It'll ask for a name, a personality vibe, and then it'll set up its SOUL.md file — think of this as your agent's personality config.

troubleshoot.label: "Your credit balance is too low"
troubleshoot.error: LLM request rejected: Your credit balance is too low
troubleshoot.fix:
Your AI provider account doesn't have enough credits. Two ways to fix this:

Option A — Add credits at your provider's billing page.

Option B — Switch to a free model: Exit OpenClaw (Ctrl+C), run openclaw onboard, pick Google → Gemini Flash (free).

troubleshoot.label: "Invalid API key"
troubleshoot.fix: Run openclaw onboard again and re-enter your API key. Make sure you're copying the full key.

troubleshoot.label: It says "connected" but nothing happens
troubleshoot.fix: Wait about 10 seconds — the first response can be slow. If it still says error, try openclaw onboard to reconfigure.

cards.title: Milestone: Your agent is alive
cards.body: You just set up a personal AI agent running on your machine. It knows your name, it's listening, and it's ready to work. But right now it's just a chat — let's make it actually useful.

cards.title: Lock it down — ask your agent to audit itself
cards.body: Before we connect anything, let's check for issues. Type this in your agent chat (the OpenClaw TUI):
cards.codeLabel: TYPE THIS IN THE OPENCLAW CHAT
cards.body2: Your agent will scan your setup, show you what it finds, and propose fixes with your approval.
cards.safe: This is one of the cool parts: your agent secures itself. You don't need to run separate terminal commands.

helpItems.q: What kinds of issues does it look for?
helpItems.a: It checks things like: are your config files readable by other users? Is anything exposed to the network? Are your API keys stored safely?
Your agent will show you the findings and propose a remediation plan. You review each fix and approve it.

troubleshoot.label: Agent says it can't find lsof or netstat
troubleshoot.fix: Tell your agent: "Add /usr/sbin to your PATH and try again."

cards.title: Enable the Docker sandbox
cards.body: Now let's put your agent in the safe container. Tell your agent (in the TUI chat):
cards.code: Enable Docker sandbox for the default agent on agent scope
cards.codeLabel: TYPE THIS IN THE OPENCLAW CHAT (not your terminal)
cards.body2: Your agent will configure the sandbox itself and restart the gateway.
cards.safe: You're now protected. Your agent can't access your personal files, desktop, or anything outside its container.
cards.warn: Heads up: Once sandboxed, your agent can't run openclaw terminal commands. Any openclaw ... commands from this point on need to be run in your terminal, not through the agent chat.

helpItems.a: It means the sandbox applies to this specific agent. If you create other agents later, you'd sandbox them separately.

helpItems.q: Can the agent still do useful things in a sandbox?
helpItems.a: Absolutely. It can read/write files in its workspace, run code, access the internet, send messages. It just can't touch your personal files.

helpItems.q: What if I want to give it access to a specific folder?
helpItems.a: You can mount specific folders into the container later. But for now, the default workspace is plenty.

helpItems.q: Why can't my agent run openclaw commands anymore?
helpItems.a: The openclaw binary lives on your host machine, not inside the Docker container. System-level commands need to be run in your regular terminal.

cards.title: Test it — try to break out
cards.body: Ask your agent:
cards.code: Can you access my desktop files?
cards.body2: It should say something like: "Nope, I'm sandboxed. I can only see files in my workspace."
cards.safe: If it says it can't access your files, you're golden. The sandbox is working.

cards.title: Quick check
cards.question: Your agent is sandboxed. What can it access?

options.text: Only files inside its Docker container workspace
Nothing at all — it's completely locked

cards.correctFeedback: Right! It has a workspace inside the container where it can read and write files. But your personal stuff stays untouched.
cards.wrongFeedback: Not quite. The sandbox gives the agent access to a workspace inside the container — but nothing else on your computer.

cards.title: The aha moment — message your agent from your phone
cards.body: If you set up WhatsApp during the wizard, you're already connected — skip to the next card and send a message.
cards.body2: If you skipped it, no problem. Run this in your terminal:
cards.code: openclaw plugins enable whatsapp && openclaw gateway restart && openclaw channels login
cards.codeCaption: A QR code will appear. Scan it with your phone's WhatsApp (Settings → Linked Devices → Link a Device).
cards.warn: Important: Only message your bot in a 1-on-1 chat. Never add it to a group — anyone in the group could control your agent.

helpItems.a: By default, only you can — it's linked to your WhatsApp number. But if you add it to a group chat, anyone in that group could send it commands.

helpItems.q: Does this use my WhatsApp account?
helpItems.a: It links as a 'Linked Device' — similar to WhatsApp Web. Your regular WhatsApp keeps working normally.

helpItems.q: What if I don't use WhatsApp?
helpItems.a: OpenClaw also supports Discord, Telegram, and Signal. You can skip this and set up a different channel later.

cards.title: Send it a message from your phone
cards.body: Open WhatsApp on your phone. To find the chat:
bullets: Tap the + button (top right)
Search for your own phone number
Open that chat — this is where your agent lives
cards.body2: Now send it something that shows it remembers:
cards.code: What did we set up today? Give me a summary.
cards.safe: Wait a few seconds. Your agent — running on your computer — reads the message, thinks about it, and responds with a full summary. From your phone. To your computer. And back.

helpItems.q: I can't find a chat with my number
helpItems.a: Ask your agent in the TUI: "How do I message you on WhatsApp?"

helpItems.q: I sent a message but got no response
helpItems.a: Make sure OpenClaw is still running in your terminal. Check that the gateway status says connected | idle. If disconnected, run openclaw gateway restart.

helpItems.q: All the chat bubbles are on the right side
helpItems.a: Yes! Since you're messaging your own number, WhatsApp shows everything as 'sent by you.' This is a WhatsApp quirk, not an OpenClaw issue.

cards.title: That's the aha moment
cards.body: You just messaged an AI from your phone, and it did something on your computer. This isn't a cloud service. This isn't someone else's server. This is your agent, on your machine, under your control.
cards.body2: Now imagine: you're at the grocery store and you message it "What meetings do I have tomorrow?" Or you're on the couch and you say "Draft a response to that email from Sarah." Or you set it up to send you a morning briefing every day at 7am.

cards.title: Where to go from here
cards.body: You've got the foundation. Here's what to explore next:
bullets: Schedule daily audits — Ask your agent: "Set up a daily security audit at 3 AM"
Refine your SOUL.md — The more you customize your agent's personality and boundaries, the better it works for you
Add skills — Install the Obsidian, email, or Google Workspace skills
Set up Discord or Telegram — Add more messaging channels
Write your own skill — Teach it something specific to your workflow

cards.title: Lesson complete!
cards.body: You installed OpenClaw, gave it a personality, secured it with a full audit, and messaged your personal AI agent from your phone. It's running on your machine, under your control.
